title: Upgrade OO Containerized on OpenShift
content:
This topic outlines steps to upgrade OO Containerized on Red Hat OpenShift. 

The upgrade process may take 20 to 30 minutes based on the number of tenants, which may impact flow execution.

Perform the following tasks to upgrade OO Containerized deployment.

Download the new charts package

You need to download the tar file from the Software Licenses and Downloads website to a bastion host. Do the following:

  1. Download the oo-helm-charts-1.x.x+26.x.x.zip file from the Software Licenses and Downloads (SLD) website.
  2. Copy the file to a temporary directory on a bastion host. 
  3. Unzip the package: 
    cd /path/to/oo_package_zip
unzip oo-helm-charts-1.x.x+26.x.x.zip

The following table describes the essential files inside the OO Containerized chart package:

Name

File

OO Helm chart file

oo-helm-charts-1.x.x+26.x.x/oo-helm-charts/charts/oo-1.x.x+26.x.x.tgz
Example Persistent Volume (PV) and Persistent Volume Claims (PVC) yaml files PV templates:
oo-helm-charts-1.x.x+26.x.x/oo-helm-charts/samples/persistent_storage/volumes.yaml

PVC templates:
oo-helm-charts-1.x.x+26.x.x/oo-helm-charts/samples/persistent_storage/claims.yaml

README file for PV:
oo-helm-charts-1.x.x+26.x.x/oo-helm-charts/samples/persistent_storage/README

Download and upload new OO images

For details, see Download container images and Upload container images.

Get values.yaml file and update

In the following commands, the command line tool yq is part of the OPTIC Management Toolkit (OMT) 2023.05, available in the /opt/cdf/bin/yq directory. Make sure that the version of yq is 4.6.1. 

  1. Run the following command to get values.yaml file from the previous OO deployment.  
    helm get values <oo_install_name> -n <oo_namespace> > /path/to/previous_deployment_values.yaml
    Check the newly added parameters on the Create values.yaml for OO Containerized on OpenShift page to understand if other values than the default ones must be configured.
  2. Run the following command on the bastion host to clean old image versions from previous_deployment_values.yaml.   
        
<OMT_install_directory>/bin/yq eval 'del(.global.busybox)' -i /path/to/previous_deployment_values.yaml
<OMT_install_directory>/bin/yq eval 'del(.global.opensuse)' -i /path/to/previous_deployment_values.yaml
<OMT_install_directory>/bin/yq eval 'del(.global.vaultRenew)' -i /path/to/previous_deployment_values.yaml
<OMT_install_directory>/bin/yq eval 'del(.global.vaultInit)' -i /path/to/previous_deployment_values.yaml
<OMT_install_directory>/bin/yq eval 'del(.. | select(has("image")).image)' -i /path/to/previous_deployment_values.yaml
<OMT_install_directory>/bin/yq eval 'del(.. | select(has("imageTag")).imageTag)' -i /path/to/previous_deployment_values.yaml
<OMT_install_directory>/bin/yq eval 'del(.ootenants-sync.version)' -i /path/to/previous_deployment_values.yaml
  3. Run the following commands on the bastion host to get the autopass database name and user using the OO Containerized values.yaml file: 
    APLSDBNAME=$(echo `<OMT_install_directory>/bin/yq e '.autopass.deployment.database.dbName' /path/to/previous_deployment_values.yaml`) && echo $APLSDBNAME
APLSDBUSER=$(echo `<OMT_install_directory>/bin/yq e '.autopass.deployment.database.user' /path/to/previous_deployment_values.yaml`) && echo $APLSDBUSER
  4. Run the following commands on the bastion host to get the autopass-migration database name and user using the OO Containerized values.yaml file: 
    APLSMIGRATIONDBNAME=$(echo `<OMT_install_directory>/bin/yq e '.autopass-migration.deployment.database.dbName' /path/to/previous_deployment_values.yaml`) && echo $APLSMIGRATIONDBNAME 
APLSMIGRATIONDBUSER=$(echo `<OMT_install_directory>/bin/yq e '.autopass-migration.deployment.database.user' /path/to/previous_deployment_values.yaml`) && echo $APLSMIGRATIONDBUSER
  5. Compare autopass and autopass-migration database name and user: 
    [[ $APLSDBNAME == $APLSMIGRATIONDBNAME ]] && echo "The values of AutoPass database name and AutoPass migration database name is the same."
[[ $APLSDBUSER == $APLSMIGRATIONDBUSER ]] && echo "The values of AutoPass database user and AutoPass migration database user is the same."

    If the output of the command shows as below, skip the following steps.

    The values of AutoPass database name and AutoPass migration database name is the same.
The values of AutoPass database user and AutoPass migration database user is the same.
  6. Update database connection information in the autopass-migration section of the yaml file. Run the following commands on the bastion host: 
    <OMT_install_directory>/bin/yq e '.autopass-migration.deployment.database.dbName = "'${APLSDBNAME}'"' -i /path/to/previous_deployment_values.yaml
<OMT_install_directory>/bin/yq e '.autopass-migration.deployment.database.user = "'${APLSDBUSER}'"' -i /path/to/previous_deployment_values.yaml
  7. Verify that the previous_deployment_values.yaml file was correctly updated. Run the following command on the bastion host:  
    cat /path/to/previous_deployment_values.yaml

    You should see the following update in the previous_deployment_values.yaml file:

    [user@host values]# cat /path/to/previous_deployment_values.yaml
global:
# [...]
autopass-migration: 
  [...]
  deployment:
    database:
      dbName: <aplsdbname>
      user: <aplsdbuser>
# [...]

Upgrade OO Containerized

The upgrade consists of three stages:

  • Pre-upgrade hooks: Three Kubernetes jobs run first. These are responsible for upgrading the databases of the OO components and tailoring some IDM resources. If these jobs run successfully, the upgrade process continues with rolling out the new version of OO pods. 
    If these jobs fail, the upgrade process stops.
  • Rolling update: This is the stage where the OO pods are upgraded to the new version through a rolling update strategy. 
  • Post upgrade: A Kubernetes job runs as soon as the pre-upgrade hooks complete, and waits till all the OO components are rolled out to the new version before it runs. Its purpose is to upgrade all OO RAS pods in the OO namespace in a sequential order. This step takes about 5 minutes per RAS.

To upgrade OO Containerized, follow these steps:

Don't run any OO flows when you're upgrading OO Containerized.
  1. Run the following command to upgrade OO Containerized: 
    helm upgrade <oo_install_name> -n <oo_namespace> <OO chart file> -f <previous_deployment_values.yaml> --timeout 30m

    Where:
    <oo_install_name> is the name of the OO deployment that you specified when installing OO.
    <oo_namespace> is the unique namespace of the OO deployment.
    <OO_chart_file> is the new tar file containing the OO installation charts.
    <previous_deployment_values.yaml-path> is an absolute path of previous_deployment_values.yaml file.

    For example:

    helm upgrade oo-prod -n oo-prod oo-helm-charts-1.x.x+26.x.x/oo-helm-charts/charts/oo-1.x.x+26.x.x.tgz -f /path/to/previous_deployment_values.yaml --timeout 30m

    You can run this command with the --dry-run an argument to simulate an upgrade.

    On successful completion of pre-upgrade hooks, you will see a message similar to the following. Completing pre-upgrade hooks takes about 3 to 4 minutes.

        
Release "<oo_install_name>" has been upgraded. Happy Helming!

[...]

Thank you for installing OpenText Operations Orchestration - 2*.*.

The deployment is in progress, you can check the status using the following command:
   `watch kubectl get pods -n <oo_namespace>`

*********************************************************************************
** WARNING:                                                                    **
**                                                                             **
**  1. If you referenced a values.yaml file for installing OO, you must        **
**  manage access to this file carefully as it contains sensitive information. **
**  OpenText recommends restricting access by leveraging file permissions,     **
**  by moving the file to a secure location, or by simply deleting the file.   **
**  Failing to secure values.yaml may expose the system to increased           **
**  security risks. You understand and agree to assume all associated risks    **
**  and hold OpenText harmless for the same. It always remains the             **
**  Customer's sole responsibility to assess its own regulatory and business   **
**  requirements. OpenText does not represent or warrant that its              **
**  products comply with any specific legal or regulatory standards            **
**  applicable to Customer in conducting Customer's business.                  **
**                                                                             **
*********************************************************************************

    After completing pre-upgrade hooks, Helm starts upgrading OO components.

  2. Run the following command to make sure that all OO pods are ready. If the command returns a blank output, then all the OO pods are ready.
    kubectl get pod -n <oo_namespace> |grep -v 1/1|grep -v 2/2|grep -v 3/3|grep -v Completed
  3. Access the OO page at https://<EXTERNAL_ACCESS_HOST>:<EXTERNAL_ACCESS_PORT>/oo and make sure that the OO Containerized state is fully up.

Related topic

To fix the "[OO RAS] Error: Must define value for all six parameters"  error during the upgrade, see Upgrade fails with [OO RAS] Error: Must define value for all six parameters.
